Vox Homepage
By Zachary Crockett
Updated Nov 22, 2016

The internet often presents the narrative of massive "islands" of plastic in the ocean, but the reality is quite different. A map by New Zealand–based data visualization firm Dumpark reveals that the ocean's plastic is not centralized but prevalent in small confetti-like pieces. Each white dot on the map represents 20 kilograms (44 pounds) of plastic, amounting to 593 million pounds of plastic on the ocean’s surfaces.

The data used for the map comes from a 2014 paper called "Plastic Pollution in the World’s Oceans" by oceanographer Marcus Eriksen, who found 5.25 trillion pieces of plastic in the oceans. Most of this plastic is microplastics, and the North Pacific is the most affected region, accounting for nearly one-third of the plastic pollution.

Efforts to mitigate plastic pollution involve not only individual contributions but also changes at the industry level, such as recovering 100 percent of products or making them environmentally harmless.
